name: Motion
htmlBanner:
Motion

Momentum's motion design enhances interactions, bridging the gap between humans and interfaces. Without it, interactions feel robotic, lacking the expected flow.

Anatomy.html:
How motion is done

To make creating motion and motion specs simpler, we need to divide them into key elements. First is the actual object being animated. Second is the interaction that triggers the motion. And third is the motion itself (property/state change in time), timing, and easing.

Elements

Sentiment indicates the meaning or role of the color. By using it, designers and developers can reduce the superstition about color design and systematically manage color.

Objects/Components

Motion objects can be shapes, components, or typography. Pretty much any object can move with motion.
In Figma, you can easily set up motion between two predefined component variants from the Momentum library.

Interactions

Interactions are the motion's triggers. They define what action starts the motion. This applies mainly to UI animations.

Properties

Properties are the specific object parameters changing to create the motion. These include (and are not limited to) position, opacity, scale, rotation, etc.

Changing component variant

Changing the size of object. Width, Height, or both. (x,y)

Changing opacity of the object. (0% to 100%)

Changing component variant

Changing the size of object. Width, Height, or both. (x,y)

Changing opacity of the object. (0% to 100%)

Duration

Duration is calculated based on the size of the motion. Motion’s duration should be dynamic based on the size of the animation. The larger the change in distance (traveled) or size (scaling) of the element, the longer the animation takes.

Easing

Easing adds life to motion by providing natural rests and custom acceleration and deceleration. Objects in real life don’t just start and stop instantly and rarely move at a constant speed.

Duration

Purpose

Easings

Purpose

Presentative

Linear

This is the best easing for presenting information or product when a constant speed with no emphasis is required.

Productive

InOutSine

This is the best easing for functional, quick movement. Productive motion is appropriate for micro-interactions such as button states, dropdowns, and revealing additional information.

Presentative

InOutCubic

This is the best easing for presenting information or product when a constant speed with no emphasis is required.

Productive

CSS to AfterEffects

This is the best easing for functional, quick movement. Productive motion is appropriate for micro-interactions such as button states, dropdowns, and revealing additional information.

Hand-off

Evaluation Checklist

Before you hand off your motion design, check if it answers these questions.

  • What problem is your motion solving?
  • Does it enhance the user’s understanding of an action?
  • Do user actions receive immediate feedback that’s seen and felt?
  • Did you use the appropriate durations and easing curves?
  • Is each motion individually considered?
  • Is the motion effective across all screen sizes?  Keep in mind that mobile screens usually miss subtle motions.
  • Is your motion unobtrusive?  The best interface motion often goes unnoticed because it keeps users engaged with their tasks. Do average users repeatedly notice your motion? If so, consider removing or minimizing it.

Motion Specs

When you hand off motion design to engineers, create motion specs to help them develop the motion in the code.

Use elements descriptions in the Anatomy section of this guideline in your motion specs.

Don’t forget to attach Mp4 preview file of the motion design!

Hand-off Anatomy

Keyframes to miliseconds

AfterEffects timeline doesn’t show miliseconds, but you can easily create a clock in your project that will show the time of the current frame in miliseconds.

Changing component variant

Twirl down this layer, twirl down text, ALT click the stopwatch on the Source text property.

In the expression field that opens in the timeline, replace the text with: Math.round(time*1000)+" ms"

Click out of the text field into a blank area of the timeline.

The text will now show the time of the current frame in milliseconds.

Principles.html:
Purpose

Why?

Momentum’s motion design is vital for creating polished interactions. Motion, in general, is a natural movement that aids in building the human-to-interface bridge. Without it, interactions feel robotic as they lose the flow that users may expect.

How?

It’s important for Momentum’s motion guidelines to facilitate flow without becoming a focal point. Showy motion graphics have their place, but in a work environment, they need to be brief, simple, and consistent.

Focus

Motion helps ease users through the experience. It helps achieve a transition, giving clear guidance for user orientation. Good motion provides direction.

Inform

Motion helps to convey a higher sense of performance that builds trust and intimacy. Intuitive, suitable, and reassuring.  Good motion gives feedback.

Emotion

Motion helps make our UIs feel alive, adding a touch of delight or 'pep' to various interactions.  Good motion makes illustrations move.

Tools

Figma

Figma prototyping has some basic animation capabilities. You can use Figma to create simple UI transitions, micro-interactions, etc.

Good for
  • Simple prototypes
  • Simple transitions
  • Simple micro-interactions
Pros
  • Full integration with Momentum Design library
  • Easy to use
  • Creates working prototypes
Cons
  • Limited animating options
  • No animation timeline to create choreography (eg. delays between two animated elements)
  • Not super stable
  • Can’t export motion files (lottie, .gif, .mp4, etc.)

Protopie

Protopie is best for creating advanced UI prototypes with animated buttons, transitions, micro-interactions, etc.

Good for
  • Prototypes
  • Transitions
  • Micro-interactions
Pros
  • Good integration with Figma
  • Easy to use
  • Advanced animation options
  • Creates working prototypes
  • Creates Motion Specs for developers
  • Supports json files
Cons
  • Limited animating options
  • No animation timeline to create choreography (eg. delays between two animated elements)
  • Not super stable
  • Can’t export motion files (lottie, .gif, .mp4, etc.)

After Effects

After Effects is best for creating expressive brand-related moments like animated illustrations, reactions, marketing videos, etc.

Good for
  • Animated illustrations
  • Animated UI objects
  • Marketing videos
Pros
  • Enormous animation capabilities
  • Can export lots of animation file formats
  • Adobe Suite software integration
Cons
  • No Figma integration
  • Rather hard to learn
  • Can’t create prototypes

File Types

Lottie (Vector file)

Vector, scalable, animation file format that’s tiny, high-quality, interactive, and can be manipulated at runtime.

SVG (Vector file)

Vector, scalable, animation file format that’s tiny, high-quality, interactive, and can be manipulated at runtime. Have some limitations compared to Lottie.

GIF (Raster file)

Raster, non-scallable format. Supports one-time and looping animations. Have serious color limitations.

Mp4 (Raster file)

Raster, non-scallable format. Supports one-time and looping animations.

Lottie file

Good for
  • Animated illustrations
  • Onboarding animations
  • Meeting reactions
  • Web animations
Pros
  • Light
  • Vector based
  • Scalable
Cons
  • Not always supported on particular devices & operating systems. No Figma integration You should ALWAYS consult with Engineer when using Lottie file

Integration

To create a Lottie File, you will need to create your animation in After Effects and export it using the Bodymovin plugin.

Step 1
  • Open AE animationAnimated illustrations
Step 2
  • Click on: Window > Extensions > Bodymoovin
Step 3
  • Export with standard settings

SVG File

Good for
  • Animated illustrations
  • Onboarding animations
  • Meeting reactions
  • Web animations
Pros
  • Light
  • Vector based
  • Scalable
Cons
  • Path animations not supported. Not always supported on particular devices & operating systems. You should ALWAYS consult with Engineer when using Lottie file

Integration

To create an Animated SVG file, you will need to create a .json Lottie file first. Then open it in the Keyshape app with Lottie format installed and export it to an SVG file.

Step 1
  • Open lottie file in keyshape app
Step 2
  • Click on File > Export...
Step 3
  • Save with these settings Format: SVG Animation: CSS Animation Check ‘Write motion paths as transforms Object IDs: Normal Loop: Forever

GIF File

Good for
  • Animated illustrations
  • Onboarding animations
  • Reactions
Pros
  • Easy to implement
Cons
  • Color palette limited to 256 colors
  • Heavy
  • Transparency not fully supported. No opacity.
